definition: Fraud pattern detection identifies potentially unfair claims practices, deceptive tactics, or suspicious patterns in insurer communications. This is risk assessment, not accusation.

riskLevels.label: Low Risk
riskLevels.description: Communication appears standard and appropriate. No suspicious patterns detected.

riskLevels.label: Moderate Risk
riskLevels.description: Some language or patterns may be concerning. Review recommended, but may be standard practice.

riskLevels.label: High Risk
riskLevels.description: Multiple suspicious patterns or concerning language detected. Professional review strongly recommended.

suspiciousPatterns.description: Unreasonable delays in response, investigation, or payment without clear justification
Incorrect interpretation or misapplication of policy language
indicators: Claiming coverage doesn't exist when it does
Incorrect application of deductibles or limits

suspiciousPatterns.description: Requesting documents that are unnecessary, already provided, or not relevant
indicators: Requesting documents not required by policy

suspiciousPatterns.description: Setting deadlines that are unreasonably short or not required by policy or law
indicators: Demanding immediate response to complex requests
Setting deadlines shorter than policy requires
Threatening consequences for missing unreasonable deadlines

scoringGuidelines: Score conservatively - not all delays or issues indicate fraud.
Look for patterns, not isolated incidents.
Flag language that is threatening, misleading, or deceptive.
Suggest professional review for high-risk situations.
Never accuse anyone of crimes - only identify risk patterns.
